body_content.explanation: an area of darkness, caused by light being blocked by something:
examples: The children were playing, jumping on each other's shadows.
Jamie followed his mother around all day like a shadow.
The sun shone through the leaves, casting/throwing shadows on the lawn.
This corner of the room is always in shadow (= slight darkness).

body_content.explanation: an area of darkness in which people and things cannot be seen:
examples: Someone jumped out of the shadows and grabbed my handbag.

body_content.explanation: a small dark area of skin under your eye:
examples: She put on some make-up to cover the dark shadows under her eyes.

body_content.explanation: to be very close to a larger building or place:
examples: His workshop was in the shadow of the great church of San Paolo Maggiore.

body_content.explanation: to be in a situation in which something unpleasant either seems likely to happen and to have a bad effect on your life, or is already having a bad effect on your life:
examples: We are all living under the shadow of war.
It is a tragic story, but there is a shadow of hope.
There isn't a shadow of doubt that you've made the right decision.

body_content.explanation: If something is true beyond a shadow of (a) doubt, there is no doubt that it is true:
examples: This is without a shadow of a doubt the best movie I've seen all year.

body_content.explanation: someone who follows another person everywhere:
examples: "I think we have a shadow on our tail," muttered the detective.
Ever since he was able to walk, Stephen has been his older brother's shadow (= has followed him and copied his actions).

body_content.explanation: a person who follows someone else while they are at work in order to learn about that person's job

examples: The police think that the robbers shadowed their victims for days before the crime.
The euro has closely shadowed the dollar.

body_content.explanation: to follow someone else while they are at work in order to learn about that person's job:
examples: Your first week in the job will be spent shadowing one of our more experienced employees.
We came across a glade shadowed by large trees.

body_content.explanation: to make a person unhappy or to make their life less happy:
examples: Mental illness had shadowed him for more than a decade.

body_content.explanation: used in the title of important politicians in the main opposition party (= the party not in government):
examples: the Shadow Foreign Secretary
the Shadow Cabinet
